newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: IAEA says 443 nuclear plants operating worldwide.
newsitem.headline: IAEA says 443 nuclear plants operating worldwide.

text.p: Five new nuclear power plants came on stream in 1996, bringing the total number currently operating around the world to 443, the United Nations nuclear agency said on Thursday.

Five nuclear power plants with a combined capacity of 5,717 megawatts of electricity were connected last year to power grids in France, Japan, Romania and the United States, the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) said.
In addition, work began on three new nuclear reactors -- two in China and one in Japan -- bringing the total number of nuclear reactors reported to be under construction to 36 in 14 countries.
The United States runs the greatest number of nuclear power plants with 110 in operation. France comes second with 57, followed by Japan with 53.
Ukraine, site of the world's worst nuclear accident at the Chernobyl plant in 1986, has 16 reactors in operation.
The IAEA said 17 countries relied on nuclear power plants to supply at least a quarter of their electricity needs, but in some areas of Europe it was significantly higher.

Nuclear power's share of electricity production was highest in Lithuania at 85.59 percent, followed by 77.4 percent in France and 57.2 percent in Belgium, 52.4 percent in Sweden, 44.5 percent in both Switzerland and Slovakia and 43.8 percent in Ukraine.
The IAEA said the total amount of electricity generated by nuclear power worldwide rose to 2,300 terawatt-hours in 1996, more than the world's total electricity generation from all sources in 1958.
Nuclear power plants provided about 17 percent of the world's electricity production in 1996, it said.
